results.title: Fool for love
results.creator_credit: Cannon Group, Menahem Golan, Yoram Globus and Robert Altman
results.brief_description: Robert Altman (The Player, McCabe and Mrs Miller, Nashville, Gosford Park) adapts Sam Shepard’s one room play with mixed results. Shepard plays Eddie, a handsome cowboy drifter who arrives in a depressing New Mexico roadside motel, lugging a trailer and horses. The aim of Eddie’s visit is to be re-united with the voluptuous May, a barmaid at this barren pit stop’s hotel. For her part May is being wooed by another man but is inextricably drawn to Eddie, despite the proven destructive nature of their union. Over the course of the evening she and Eddie argue violently and make up passionately as the heart-rending history of their relationship, replete with flashbacks, unfurls. Harry Dean Stanton plays a barfly whose identity holds a key role to these lovers’ sorrow. “Fool for love” garnered mostly negative reviews and found a very limited audience, regardless of praise for Basinger’s bravura performance. Most decried the device of opening up the play, outside of its claustrophobic one room structure, in favour of a wider locale, which may have robbed it of the intimate tensions generated by the ill-matched pair battling it out in a confined space. But despite this the incendiary relationship between the principal characters is astutely portrayed, achieving a suitably tragic tone within a desolate setting.

results.creator_credit: Educational Communications and Bortnick Film Productions

results.title: Foods: fads and facts
results.brief_description: Discusses the effects of pesticides, preservatives and additives on foods and illustrates how government authorities maintain adequate safety levels on foods through constant supervision of food marketing. Also considers whether organic foods have any more nutritional value than foods grown with help of scientific knowledge. Suitable for secondary level.

results.title: Foods and nutrition
results.brief_description: A study of the metabolic processes of the body, illustrated by animated diagrams showing the distribution of carbohydrates, proteins, fats, minerals, and vitamins, and by experiments carried out on white mice.

results.title: Food: the story of a peanut butter sandwich
results.creator_credit: Learning Corporation of America, International Cinemedia Center and George Kaczender
results.brief_description: At a children’s party a contest is held to see who can make the most interesting sandwich. The popularity of peanut butter leads to an inquiry into food processing, its mechanics and economics. The filmmaker poses questions to the children about the origin of food, especially peanut butter, filling in the historical, geographic, cultural and other factors.

results.title: Food: a multi-cultural feast
results.brief_description: Written by Jeffrey Schrank, the main tenet of this video is that taste is a cultural bias - you eat/enjoy what your culture teaches you is edible/enjoyable and similarly reject as inedible what your culture rejects too. So what may make a person from one culture gag (monkey brains, haggis, raw fish, sheep eyeballs, cheese, frog’s legs, pigs feet etc) yet become delicacies in another culture? The program also looks at the physical/philosophical differences of how we eat. The second half provides an interesting look at the multi-cultural origins of many foods that have became part of the American national diet and its identity as well as looking at the influence of slaves, native Americans and immigrants on the eating habits of Americans.

results.title: Food Victoria: a whole world of food (MAC & PC)
results.creator_credit: Food Victoria, Victorian Dairy Industry Authority and Multimedia Victoria
results.brief_description: Victoria produces a third of Australia’s raw and processed food. The multimedia interactive program is divided into four sections: Victoria, Dairy, Stone Fruit and a Directory based on a supermarket interface. A wealth of information with excellent graphics and video presentations.

results.title: Food that builds good health
results.brief_description: A young boy called Art is not eating a balanced diet, so is weak and lethargic. A school demonstration with two guinea pigs on different diets convinces Art that he should change his eating habits.

results.title: Food science: kitchen mysteries revealed
results.brief_description: What do toilet paper and ice-cream have in common? What does Newton’s Law of Rotational Inertia have to do with eggs? This program looks at the scientific principles and explanations behind traditional preparation of everyday foods. In question and answer form it examines such things as: Why does cream stay whipped but milk doesn’t? Why does popcorn pop in oil but not in water? Why do some eggs crack but others stay whole when boiled? Why do we beat eggs and sift flour? Why do cut onions cause tears but uncut onions do not? In posing these questions the program includes the scientific reason behind processes and provides a clear, entertaining and useful tool suited to secondary level science students.
